BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and northwesterly wind, further wind slabs formed in the last few days in places that are protected from the wind. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Wind slabs are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. In particular on very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in the various wind slab layers and reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m. The wind was strong. The wind has transported the new snow significantly. The more recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger. Wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
An appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes in all aspects in particular below approximately 2600 m. They can be released at any time of day or night. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.

The wind slabs of the last few days are in some cases still prone to triggering on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. The clearly visible wind slabs are to be avoided in very steep terrain.
On extremely steep sunny slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very mild. The weather conditions brought about a substantial stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. Wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2600 m.

The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The snowpack will be wet all the way through below approximately 2000 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to rapid softening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Gliding snow represents the main danger.
Wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind, sometimes deep wind slabs formed by Saturday in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
They are easy to recognise and can in some cases be released easily especially at their margins, in particular on extremely steep slopes.
Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases, caution is to be exercised on steep shady slopes. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
The weather will be mild. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation, in particular on very steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes, caution is to be exercised in particular in steep rocky terrain, and on very steep grassy slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2300 m a lot of snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
More recent wind slabs are to be found also areas not adjacent to ridgelines. As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to moistening of the old snowpack in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads at their margins in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs are clearly recognisable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects as well as at a distance from ridgelines: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind: Fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially on very steep shady slopes.
Until the temperature drops more moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain, and at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface during the last few days. More recent wind slabs are to be found also areas not adjacent to ridgelines.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are sometimes critical for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially above the tree line. Wind slabs can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach medium size.
Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very mild. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
The weather conditions will bring about a slow stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2000 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The storm force wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly. The fresh and older wind slabs represent the main danger. Avalanches can in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. This applies in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Between approximately 2400 and 3000 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. They can in isolated cases be released by small loads. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, as well as in gullies and bowls.
Avalanches can in very isolated cases penetrate deep layers, especially on very steep shady slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days are lying on soft layers on shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.
Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. The weather will be mild.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The more recent wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized slab avalanches are possible.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases.

On rocky sunny slopes individual mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a gradual change towards better conditions. A quite favourable avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche conditions are generally favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The somewhat older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes. Mostly avalanches are rather small.

On very steep sunny slopes individual mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be quite stable. The wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A quite favourable avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially in areas close to the tree line and above the tree line. Wind slabs can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very mild. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
The weather conditions will bring about a slow stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2000 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase in particular on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, at elevated altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack above approximately 2400 m.
In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Hardly any small avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Very isolated avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitude and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs are to be found in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. They are very small. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to softening of the old snowpack. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint. There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects hardly any snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
